Interdating The Negro point of view
By HOLLACE GOLDBERG Last in a series
I am a boy. I am a girl. My skin is a shade darker and my hair a bit thicker than most students. I play the dating game differently too. I am a Negro who has become integrated into the fabric of the University, and I stay aloof from all-Negro social cliques. People who share my perspective often hold similar, though not identical points of view.
“I think white girls are de- finitely more friendly than white boys,” related a pretty young freshman. “I feel that white girls are particularly friendly with Negro boys. There is such a limited amount of Negro boys that this really gets on my nerves.”
“That’s typical female jeal- ousy,” laughed a Negro boy, hear ing these comments. But the attractive coed had more to say.
"If it was a fair interchange, I might not mind,” she said. “But white boys show little in- terest in Negro girls, I have the distinct feeling,” she said, “that when a white boy sees an attractive Negro girl, it crosses his mind that she is Negro” and he then pays no further attention to her.
“They must have some particu- lar impression that Negro girls are dirty and ignorant. I’ve really tried to figure out the mental processes involved be- cause you can’t tell me that boys won’t recognize a nice look- ing girl right away.”
On the other side of the dating game is Dave, also a Negro. He notes that often white girls exer- cise a certain friendliness to- ward him, but he exercises some caution in interdating.
“You can ask a girl out right away--if you like getting shot down!” he commented. “But most of the time in your associations you basically know who would (go out with you) and who wouldn’t,” he said. If a Negro boy and a white girl get to know each other and build up an ex- change, “you ask her out then.”
Among the students interview- ed, boys have interdated more frequently than girls. One coed who has been asked out by white boys has always “declined. I might feel a little strange,” she explained, “but the person I am with might feel worse.”
"My father just wouldn’t ap- prove,” offered another coed. “I am not going to say ‘No, I never will interdate.’ If it comes along, I might. But... I think the chances are less for me than for a Negro boy.”
Most of these Negroes have definite views about the colored students who sit together in the Main Dining Hall and in the Stu- dent Union. “It’s sociological,” explained one Negro. “These kids, for the most part, come from schools where there were 90 per cent Negroes. They have never been in an integrated en- vironment and therefore remain together here.”
“They're mostly commuters (in the Union)," analyzed an- other. “They just go to the Union because there is really nothing else for them to do in between classes--except to study. You can’t do that all the time, and it is nice to relax in the Union.”
"To me, the Student Union Negro is the Negro that every body expects to see,” asserted a Negro coed with much resent- ment. “I don’t go to the Union,” she continued. "I don’t care to classify myself. I find it posi- tively revolting. All my people are congregated in one section playing pinochle, laughing and talking.
"When I sit with the Negroes in the dining hall," she added, "they make me feel more like a Negro than white people do." A Negro clique, she said, im- plies that "the white world has me down and I have to go hunt up my people.”
"I picked the University of Maryland as opposed to Negro colleges in Baltimore. I still have to live in a white man’s world, therefore I have to learn to live with them. The only way you can let people know that you are like them is to associate with them."
Negro students who spend their
Negro should 'learn to live' in white world
time in the Union, however, dis- agree with these viewpoints. "These were my friends in high school,” professed one boy. "I came to college and stayed with them. It’s natural to stay with people you know. Many white students segregate themselves, too, and only stay with people they associated with prior to college.”
The Negro community on cam- pus is not homogeneous in ideas-- nor can the Negro community be considered an identifiable sub- group. Some Negro students stay segregated. Others inte- grate to varying degrees. Like all individuals, each Negro has a distinct set of opinions. Even college holds a different place in each one’s scheme of values.
"I think college is a place where you do a lot of learning," expressed one Negro. "All your life you have been taught this and that. Now your intellect begins to take over... You learn whether it was all a big hoax."
In this generation, he reflected, there are many opportunities for whites and Negroes to interre- late, many more opportunities than "our parents” had. Inter- racial contact stimulates thought and discussion.
"Sooner or later I hope every- body will be one big happy family —-all mixed up. Things could really swing,” one Negro sug- gested. “Or, then again, we could have a recession.”
